properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued February 11 at 4:14AM EST until February 11 at 10:15AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has extended
the

* Flood Advisory for...
Habersham County in northeastern Georgia...
Rabun County in northeastern Georgia...

* Until 1015 AM EST Tuesday.

* At 400 AM EST, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated
patches of moderate rainfall are returning to Rabun and Habersham
counties after a quieter past 6 hours, when less than a quarter
inch of rainfall occurred.  The lighter rainfall allowed streams
to crest, albeit over bankfull, following widespread storm-total
rainfall of 1.75-2.25 inches since 7am Monday morning.  New rounds
of moderate rainfall will induce new runoff which will likely
keep streams elevated and cause nuisance flooding of low-lying
areas to persist.

* Additional rainfall of 1-2 inches is possible early Tuesday
morning through Tuesday afternoon.  This will exacerbate ongoing
flooding and may cause new flooding to develop.  This area may be
upgraded to a Flash Flood Warning if additional heavy
rainfall develops. Residents within low-lying areas, especially
adjacent to streams, are encouraged to stay weather aware and have
a way to receive NWS warnings.  Drivers are urged to obey all
barricades and avoid flooded roadways.

* The following streamgauge remains above Action/Advisory Stage:
Soque River at GA 197 near Clarkesville.

CURRENT Stage: 12.39 feet and falling slowly.
CREST: 12.47 feet at 2:15am.
FORECAST: The Soque River will continue to slowly fall over the
next several hours unless heavier rainfall develops. Additional
rises are possible Tuesday morning.

ACTION/ADVISORY Stage: 11.0 feet.
MINOR Flood Stage: 13.0 feet.

IMPACTS: Between 11 and 13 feet, the Soque River will begin
flooding low-lying areas adjacent to the river near Clarkesville,
including Pitts City Park.

* The headwaters of the Tallulah River also remain above bankfull, but
the river has crested and is slowly receding. Expect a slow recession
or steady levels as additional light to moderate rainfall moves over
the watershed. Additional rises are possible through Tuesday morning.

* Some locations that may experience flooding include...
Clayton, Clarkesville, Cornelia, Baldwin, Demorest, Mount Airy,
Alto, Mountain City, Tiger and Dillard.
properties.instruction:
Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.

In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are
potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded
roads. Turn around, dont drown.

If additional heavy rainfall develops, the Advisory may be upgraded to
a Flash Flood Warning. People in flood prone areas, especially along
small streams, should prepare to move to higher ground quickly if a
Flash Flood Warning is issued.
